instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
Hi guys.

I have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 with a no power issue. There was some corrosion on the backlight circuit, on <CAPACITOR>C8475</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8466</CAPACITOR> which I cleaned and re-soldered. At the moment when plugged in it goes to 20v and around 0.5-0.6 amps but then drops to 0.3amps and stays that way. On the thermal camera, <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> goes to the 40s-low 50s degrees, and also the CPU nearly 40, nothing else warms up. Even before I cleaned the corrosion there was no short anywhere and no other corrosion spots. Any idea?

Thanks :)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message: Update: Also <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> goes up to 50 degrees in about 20-30sec and continues to go up slowly

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message: Do you get CPU core voltage?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
Now yes. It was strange that <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> was overheating and not powering on while getting 20v. I took out and re-soldered <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and it powered on with just no backlight, the reason being the backlight cable was broken which I fixed and now it's all good :)

Thanks for the assistance  âœŒ :cool:
